messageBody:
This is related to the recent dicussion about testing abstract
classes, but doesn't seem to have quite been covered.

I have an abstract class Foo and (currently) two implementations of
it: FooImpl and FooSpecialImpl. As it turns out FooSpecialImpl is a
proxy too FooImpl. Currently I suspect that other Foo implementations
will also be proxies, but I'm not sure. Foo instances are returned by
a Bar (which is a Builder of sorts). The pattern of variation looks
like "run exactly the same tests as for Foo, except do this extra
work at a predefined place in the middle of the test."

Goals:

1. Must have all "generic" Foo tests to run for each kind of proxy
created without any extra coding beyond adding the new types to a
list. Otherwise it's too easy to add a new Foo test and forget to
configure it for each Foo subclass, or too easy to add a new subclass
and forget to add every Foo test to its tests.

2. Must allow for per-test variations in builder configuration.
Strongly prefer to do that without forcing it into setUp because
there are about 20 unique test configurations and I'd hate to have to
do 20 test classes.

3. Must allow addition of specific tests for a Foo subclass (for
example the FooSpecialImpl is to ensure that Foo methods run in a
designated thread, we will want some tests that verify that happens).
OK to have them in a different TestCase subclass.

4. Somewhat desire that each test remains a separate test method. If
not possible to achieve other goals with this one could accept a
solution that collapses all Foo tests into a single testFoo method.

My current tests look something like this:

public class FooTest extends TestCase {
private Foo fooUnderTest = null;

/** Set up common infrastructure. */
public void setUp() {
Bar builder = new Bar;
// Do some manipulations to builder common to all tests.
}

/** Stimulate a Foo and check its responses. */
public void runFooTest() {
// ...
}

public Foo getFoo() {
return builder.constructFoo();
}

public void testSpecificFeature() {
// set specificStuff to configuration items specific to test
builder.configure(specificStuff);
fooUnderTest = getFoo();

// Set some instance variables to configure test details
// and expected results
runFooTest();
}
}


What I really wanted to do was create a FooSpecialTest that extends
FooTest and just reimplements getFoo. Unfortunately, that does not
work (the error is '1) warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1) "No tests
found in FooSpecialTest"').

Any suggestions? Solutions that meet all requirements are preferred.
Reasons to change the requirements and accompanying solutions are a
good second choice.

Regards,

Rob
